A **glass golem**, ', is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. The glass golem is [thick-skinned](/wiki/Thick-skinned "Thick-skinned"), and is one of the stronger types of [golem](/wiki/Golem "Golem").

A glass golem has two claw attacks, and possesses [acid resistance](/wiki/Acid_resistance "Acid resistance") along with the [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") of all golems. A glass golem that is subjected to [stoning](/wiki/Stoning "Stoning") will become a [stone golem](/wiki/Stone_golem "Stone golem").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Generation

Randomly generated glass golems are always created hostile. Glass golems are always generated with 60 [hit points](/wiki/Hit_point "Hit point").[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Glass golems can generate as a result of [polypiling](/wiki/Polypiling "Polypiling") if there are enough [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") objects in a pile of items.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Glass golems leave behind several pieces of [worthless glass](/wiki/Worthless_glass "Worthless glass") in varying colors upon death [instead of a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless").[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) They are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Per [commit a1b76593](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/a1b765936f807729e1c2cf3c7a9b928e34a277f5), glass golems generate with 80 HP.

## Strategy

Glass golems can be surprisingly hard-hitting when [heroes](/wiki/Hero "Hero") first encounter them normally, but cautious and well-prepared heroes should have no problem with them. The worthless glass that they leave behind can be used to reliably identify any worthless glass in the hero's inventory and stashes via type-[naming](/wiki/Naming "Naming").

## History

The glass golem first appears in [NetHack 3.3.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.3.0 "NetHack 3.3.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including some variants based on those versions, casting [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") at a [statue](/wiki/Statue "Statue") or [figurine](/wiki/Figurine "Figurine") of a golem produces a single [meatball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball"), since any golem other than the [flesh golem](/wiki/Flesh_golem "Flesh golem") or [leather golem](/wiki/Leather_golem "Leather golem") is considered "[vegetarian](/wiki/Vegetarian "Vegetarian")" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [NetHack 3.6.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.0 "NetHack 3.6.0") via [commit d8a0f734](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/commit/d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4) so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Golem](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golem "wikipedia:Golem")***

The *gōlem* is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The glass golem is possibly based on the stained glass golem, a being that appears in the 2nd and 3rd editions of *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")* and debuts in the 2nd Edition *Monstrous Manual*. Stained glass golems are constructed to blend in with the decor of a temple or palace, and resemble flat, two-dimensional imitations of people; they remain hidden from view until unwanted visitors are seen, and the only sound they make is a tinkling sound like delicate crystal wind chimes that occurs while moving. Moving through light causes a stained glass golem to flicker and twinkle as the light refracted. Like many golems, glass golems possess a general immunity to most magic and spells, though they were extremely vulnerable to sonic and shattering spells; they healed rapidly on their own, but can also be repaired with mending spells.

## Messages

- \<The glass golem> is getting soft!

  A glass golem was hit by a flaming attack.

- \<The glass golem> melts away.

  A glass golem was submerged in [lava](/wiki/Lava "Lava").

## Variants

In variants with [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") systems, glass golems may drop additional items made of [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") upon death alongside or instead of a pile of worthless glass.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), glass golems are always generated with 140 HP.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), glass golems have one of their claw attacks replaced with a weapon attack, and [generate with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") one of the twelve following glass weapons (with an equal probability of each): a [saber](/wiki/Saber "Saber"), a [sickle](/index.php?title=Sickle\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Sickle (page does not exist)"), an [axe](/wiki/Axe "Axe"), a [stiletto](/wiki/Stiletto "Stiletto"), a [crystal sword](/wiki/Crystal_sword "Crystal sword"), a [broadsword](/wiki/Broadsword "Broadsword"), a [scimitar](/wiki/Scimitar "Scimitar"), a [rapier](/wiki/Rapier "Rapier"), a [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"), a [two-handed sword](/wiki/Two-handed_sword "Two-handed sword"), a [partisan](/wiki/Partisan "Partisan"), or a [glaive](/wiki/Glaive "Glaive").

### FIQHack

In [FIQHack](/wiki/FIQHack "FIQHack"), the glass golem's glyph is changed to '.

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), glass golems are always generated with 80 HP.

Glass golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(xNetHack\) "Object materials (xNetHack)") of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace [potions](/wiki/Potion "Potion") and other invalid items generated this way.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), glass golems can drop various items with an [object material](/wiki/Object_materials_\(EvilHack\) "Object materials (EvilHack)") of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace potions and other invalid items generated this way.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), glass golems are instantly destroyed by sonic attacks, such as the [rays](/wiki/Ray "Ray") from a [wand of noise](/wiki/Wand_of_noise "Wand of noise") - a hero in the form of a glass golem that is killed this way returns to normal form, even if they have [unchanging](/wiki/Unchanging "Unchanging").

Glass golems can drop various items with an [object material](/index.php?title=Object_materials_\(Hack%27EM\)\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Object materials (Hack'EM) (page does not exist)") of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace potions and other invalid items generated this way.

## Encyclopedia entry

Glass golems share the following [encyclopedia](/wiki/Encyclopedia "Encyclopedia") entry with other golems that lack their own entry:

"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth  
century. Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is  
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to  
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other  
menial work.  
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort  
of vegetable half-life. What life it had, too, so the story  
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its  
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the  
\`free sidereal strength of the universe.'  
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take  
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.  
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its  
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and  
destroyed it. Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless. All that was  
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in  
the Old Synagogue." ...

\[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]

### Hack'EM

The glass golem is very nearly a work of art. Built in the form of  
a stained glass knight, the creature is often built into a window  
fashioned from such glass. Thus, it usually acts as the guardian of  
a given location -- often a church or shrine.  
Glass golems, like most others, never speak or communicate in any  
way. When they move, however, they are said to produce a tinkling  
sound like that made by delicate crystal wind chimes. If moving  
through a lighted area, they strobe and flicker as the light  
striking them is broken into its component hues.  
\[ Monstrous Manual, by TSR inc. ]

==History==
The glass golem first appears in [[NetHack 3.3.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including some variants based on those versions, casting [[stone to flesh]] at a [[statue]] or [[figurine]] of a golem produces a single [[meatball]], since any golem other than the [[flesh golem]] or [[leather golem]] is considered "[[vegetarian]]" due to not being composed of normally-edible material - this is fixed in [[NetHack 3.6.0]] via {{commit|d8a0f734815d6d0d81151c7222e63efbfe3f7cd4}} so that doing so produces a live flesh golem.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Golem}}
The ''gōlem'' is an animate, anthropomorphic being that originates from Jewish folklore, and is created entirely from inanimate matter, usually clay or mud. The most famous golem narrative is "The Golem of Prague", which tells of the late 16th century rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel and his creation of a golem using clay from the Vltava River, which he brought to life to defend the Prague ghetto from anti-Semitic attacks and pogroms. In modern popular culture, the word became generalized to refer to any crude anthropomorphic construct that is made of inanimate material and brought to life by some means, with the method of animation and the resulting creation's sapience and/or sentience varying wildly.

The glass golem is possibly based on the stained glass golem, a being that appears in the 2nd and 3rd editions of ''[[Dungeons & Dragons]]'' and debuts in the 2nd Edition ''Monstrous Manual''. Stained glass golems are constructed to blend in with the decor of a temple or palace, and resemble flat, two-dimensional imitations of people; they remain hidden from view until unwanted visitors are seen, and the only sound they make is a tinkling sound like delicate crystal wind chimes that occurs while moving. Moving through light causes a stained glass golem to flicker and twinkle as the light refracted. Like many golems, glass golems possess a general immunity to most magic and spells, though they were extremely vulnerable to sonic and shattering spells; they healed rapidly on their own, but can also be repaired with mending spells.

==Variants==
In variants with [[object materials]] systems, glass golems may drop additional items made of [[glass]] upon death alongside or instead of a pile of worthless glass.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], glass golems are always generated with 140 HP.{{refsrc|makemon.c|2254|version=SLASH'EM 0.0.7E7F2}}

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], glass golems have one of their claw attacks replaced with a weapon attack, and [[Monster starting inventory|generate with]] one of the twelve following glass weapons (with an equal probability of each): a [[saber]], a [[sickle]], an [[axe]], a [[stiletto]], a [[crystal sword]], a [[broadsword]], a [[scimitar]], a [[rapier]], a [[long sword]], a [[two-handed sword]], a [[partisan]], or a [[glaive]].

===FIQHack===
In [[FIQHack]], the glass golem's glyph is changed to {{green|'}}.

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], glass golems are always generated with 80 HP.

Glass golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (xNetHack)|object material]] of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace [[potion]]s and other invalid items generated this way.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], glass golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (EvilHack)|object material]] of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace potions and other invalid items generated this way.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], glass golems are instantly destroyed by sonic attacks, such as the [[ray]]s from a [[wand of noise]] - a hero in the form of a glass golem that is killed this way returns to normal form, even if they have [[unchanging]].

Glass golems can drop various items with an [[Object materials (Hack'EM)|object material]] of glass upon death, with worthless glass acting as a fallback to replace potions and other invalid items generated this way.

==Encyclopedia entry==
Glass golems share the following [[encyclopedia]] entry with other golems that lack their own entry:
{{encyclopedia|
"The original story harks back, so they say, to the sixteenth
century. Using long-lost formulas from the Kabbala, a rabbi is
said to have made an artificial man -- the so-called Golem -- to
help ring the bells in the Synagogue and for all kinds of other
menial work.
"But he hadn't made a full man, and it was animated by some sort
of vegetable half-life. What life it had, too, so the story
runs, was only derived from the magic charm placed behind its
teeth each day, that drew down to itself what was known as the
`free sidereal strength of the universe.'
"One evening, before evening prayers, the rabbi forgot to take
the charm out of the Golem's mouth, and it fell into a frenzy.
It raged through the dark streets, smashing everything in its
path, until the rabbi caught up with it, removed the charm, and
destroyed it. Then the Golem collapsed, lifeless. All that was
left of it was a small clay image, which you can still see in
the Old Synagogue." ...
|[ The Golem, by Gustav Meyrink ]
}}

===Hack'EM===
{{encyclopedia|
The glass golem is very nearly a work of art. Built in the form of
a stained glass knight, the creature is often built into a window
fashioned from such glass. Thus, it usually acts as the guardian of
a given location -- often a church or shrine.
Glass golems, like most others, never speak or communicate in any
way. When they move, however, they are said to produce a tinkling
sound like that made by delicate crystal wind chimes. If moving
through a lighted area, they strobe and flicker as the light
striking them is broken into its component hues.
[ Monstrous Manual, by TSR inc. ]
}}
